awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019: Improving C4 Crop Tolerance for Heat Stress by Engineering Thermostable Rubisco Activase
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Sarah Stainbrook is "Improving C4 Crop Tolerance for Heat Stress by Engineering Thermostable Rubisco Activase". The host institution for the fellowship is the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center (DDPSC) and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Ru Zhang.

Global population growth, coupled with a transition to dependence on biofuels, will require a doubling of production of maize and other grain crops by 2050. However, the projected 3.5 degrees Celsius temperature increase in 2050 will reduce global maize production by 23%. Even now, heat waves such as those experienced by the U.S. in 1980, 1988 and 2012 could devastate agricultural productivity, with losses estimated at 55, 71, and 31 billion dollars, respectively. One solution to this impending food security crisis is by improving the thermotolerance of crops to withstand heat stress by focusing on Rubisco activase (Rca), the most thermosensitive enzyme involved in photosynthesis. This project will leverage naturally occurring variation in Rca in different plants to find or create a Rca enzyme variant that can improve the ability of maize to withstand high temperatures. Broader impacts include teaching a non-majors undergraduate biology class to improve science literacy and mentoring high school students from underprivileged or minority backgrounds through the Mutant Millets outreach program at the DDPSC.

C3, C4, and CAM are three different photosynthetic processes that plants use to fix carbon. One of the primary factors limiting carbon fixation during heat stress is the activation state of the carbon fixation enzyme Rubisco. Rubisco must be activated by its catalytic chaperone, Rubisco activase (Rca). It is estimated that the net photosynthesis rate of maize could be doubled at 40 degrees Celsius if a thermostable Rca could be found or created. This research will focus on identifying and isolating variant Rca enzymes from C4 crops maize and sorghum, as well as the closely related model grass, Setaria viridis. Rca isolates from these plants will be characterized by in vitro carbon assimilation assays and correlated to chlorophyll fluorescence and gas exchange measurements taken from intact plants. Heat-adapted isolates from these plants, as well as from C3, C4 and CAM plants from a variety of environments, will be similarly assayed to determine the range of naturally occurring variation in Rca thermotolerance. Additionally, protein engineering techniques will be used to improve Rca thermostability. Variants with improved properties will be introduced into S viridis to verify that the engineered thermostable enzyme improves thermotolerance of photosynthesis in the transgenic plant. Once verified, the engineered thermostable Rca will be introduced into maize. All phenotypic and biochemical data generated in this project, including from plants from diverse climates, will be added to existing genetic information maintained in a publicly accessible database and further disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. 

Keywords: thermotolerance, carbon fixation, maize, C4 photosynthesis, Rubisco activase.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When plants experience heat stress, such as a heat wave during the growing season, their ability to photosynthesize is compromised. Others have previously shown that one specific protein, called Rubisco Activase, stops working as well at high temperatures and shuts down the entire process of photosynthesis. In some plants, this is a good thing: photosynthesis during high temperatures can be damaging to the plant, and also wastes energy because of a process called photorespiration that becomes worse at high temperatures. However, other plants such as corn (called C4 plants) don't have photorespiration and are better able to cope with the damage caused by high temperatures. In these plants, we expect that photosynthesis could go faster as the temperature gets hotter. My research asked the question, does Rubisco Activase still stop working in this type of plant in the heat? If so, can we change Rubisco Activase so that it keeps working even when the plant is hot? 

My research showed that even though C4 plants don't have the problem of photorespiration and could potentially photosynthesize at high temperatures, the Rubisco Activase in C4 plants still stops functioning at high temperatures. I also showed that Rubisco Activase doesn't simply break when it gets too hot- instead, the plant deliberately turns off Rubisco Activase by making changes in the chemical composition of the chloroplast. This is an intriguing discovery because it means that if we want to change Rubisco Activase to keep working in the heat, we have to learn how and why plants turn it off, and how to interfere with that process. Ultimately, this research will help us better understand how plants perceive and respond to high temperatures and will guide the development of crops that are better able to thrive in the hotter climate of the future. 

During the COVID-19 pandemic, I worked with a group of 12 high school students and their teacher to offer them a virtual research experience. Students in my virtual research group used computer modeling of proteins to design experiments for me to perform, and then they analyzed the data, drew conclusions, and presented their work. Although they couldn’t do the experiments themselves, they developed the important scientific skills and critical thinking that are arguably more important to scientific success than specific laboratory techniques are. I tested whether students benefitted from the virtual experience and found that even though many students would prefer hands-on research, they still developed their skills and confidence. Although in-person, hands-on research experience is ideal for helping students explore a potential career, there are many situations where this type of in-person experience is not possible. Even beyond the pandemic, virtual research could benefit individuals from rural areas, individuals with mobility impairments, and other underserved groups. My work shows that COVID-era virtual programs can still provide benefits to certain groups even after the end of pandemic restrictions. 

Intellectual Merit: This work has provided insight into how Rubisco Activase functions in C4 plants during heat stress, and how plants regulate its activity while they acclimate to heat. It has also shown that students can develop valuable scientific skills and improved confidence in remote-only virtual research experiences.

Broader Impacts: By identifying the regulatory changes affecting Rubisco Activase, this work has provided direction to crop improvement efforts focused on making C4 crops more resilient to heat stress. In addition, it has provided research experiences to fourteen high school students and three undergraduates, developing both their competency and interest in scientific careers. Finally, it has provided a template for virtual research experiences for others to follow.
